title: I cash a check from casino resort 3 months ago. My bank overdraft did not cover it.Should i include this on chapter 7 CA.
question: I cash a check at casino last 12/21/12. It bounced and bank advise me to stop pay to avoid daily NSF fees. I am planning to file chapter 7 in CA. Should I include this even if I want to pay the third party? My bank closed my checking account.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Statement of financial affairs,341 meeting of creditors,Debt,Debt relief,Bankruptcy and debt,Criminal charges
answers:
Just so you know, there are the possibility of criminal charges on checks like this. Depends not he state, but the laws are common.

Bankruptcy does not prevent criminal charges.

Probably won't happen but keep that in mind.

How much was the check for? You may want to pay it before filing. If it's under $600.00 the trustee won't go after it and, in truth, would probably not go after it if it was under $1,500.00. Was this a Vegas casino? Card club? Local Indian casino? in Vegas I understand they routinely refer these bounced check cases to the DA's Office for prosecution. Is that right Dorothy? If so, better to avoid a criminal charge by paying the check. And if you got prosecuted, you be ordered to pay it back and then it would be non-dischargeable. I've had a few bounced check clients with several local Indian Casinos and never had a problem.

So what's the answer? Depends on the amount of the check and who it was writen to. I suggest discussing it in person was an experienced attorney. Give me a call if you like.

Rob Taylor, Esq.
www.affordableattorneysgroup.com

Yes, you should list the debt to the casino. As my colleagues stated, you are required to list all debts. Further, at the Meeting of Creditors the trustee will specifically ask you, while you are under oath, whether you listed all your creditors.

You should also list your bank if you had a negative balance due to the NSF fees.

I have assumed that you wrote the check. If a 3d party wrote the check to you and you were cashing that check, then you also have a claim against the person/company who wrote the check to you, which you should list on Schedule B. I am assuming that this person has not made good on the bounced check.

The prior answer is correct. You must list all debts as required by law. When you sign the petition you are swearing and affirming that you have disclosured all liabilities and assets. As pointed out in the prior answer, if you pay any creditor more than $600.00 in the ninty(90) days before filing the payment can be considered a prefence.
You have to list all debts in your schedules and statement of financial affairs. You also have to list any payments to creditors within the last 90 days on your statement of financial affairs.
